{{Use British English|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox airport | name = RAF Kaldadarnes | nativename = [[File:Ensign of the Royal Air Force.svg|90px]] | nativename-a = | nativename-r = | image = | image-width = | caption = | IATA = | ICAO = | type = Military | owner = [[Icelandic Government]] | operator = [[Royal Air Force]] | city-served = Reykjavík, Iceland | location = [[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]] | built = {{Start date|df=yes|1940}} | used = 1941-{{End date|df=yes|1945}} | elevation-f = | elevation-m = | coordinates = {{Coord|63|55|52.33|N|021|10|14.78|W|region:GB_type:airport|display=inline,title}} | latd = 63 | latm = 55 | lats = 52.33 | latNS = N | longd= 021 | longm= 10 | longs= 14.78 | longEW= W | coordinates_type = airport | coordinates_region = Iceland | pushpin_map = Iceland | pushpin_label = RAF Kaldadarnes | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Iceland }} '''Royal Air Force Station Kaldadarnes''' or more simply '''RAF Kaldadarnes''' is a former [[Royal Air Force station]], near the city of [[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]]. ==Beginnings== The station was built in 1940 by the [[British Army]] and used by the [[Royal Air Force]] from March 1941 and throughout the remainder of the [[Second World War]]. On 2 September 1942 the war artist [[Eric Ravilious]] was lost after he flew from Kaldadarnes.[http://www.cwgc.org/search/casualty_details.aspx?casualty=2471671 Casualty Details: Ravilious, Eric William], [[Commonwealth War Graves Commission]]. ==Squadrons== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- ! Sqn !! Aircraft !! Joined !! Departed !! From > To !! Notes |- | [[No. 48 Squadron RAF|48]] || [[Lockheed Hudson]] V & III || 6 January 1942 || 23 September 1942 || [[RAF Wick]] > [[RAF Sumburgh]] || Detachment only.Jefford, p.44 (No. 48 Sqn) |- | [[No. 98 Squadron RAF|98]] || [[Fairey Battle]] V
[[Hawker Hurricane]] I || 31 July 1940 || 15 July 1941 || [[RAF Gatwick]] > DB || Last Squadron move prior to being disbanded.Jefford, p.56 (No. 98 Sqn) |- | [[No. 269 Squadron RAF|269]] || [[Avro Anson]] I
[[Lockheed Hudson]] I & III || April 1940 || 6 March 1943 || [[RAF Wick]] > [[RAF Reykjavik]] || Detachment initially prior to Squadron move.Jefford, p.84 (No. 269 Sqn) |} After the cessation of hostilities of the Second World War the British Government handed the airfield over to the Icelandic Civil Aviation Authority and was used for a short while until it was closed and is now in ruins. ==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist}} ===Bibliography=== * {{cite book|author=Jefford, C G [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]],BA,RAF (Retd).|title=R.A.F Squadrons, A comprehensive record of the movement and equipment of all RAF squadrons and their antecedents since 1912|location=UK|publisher=Airlife Publishing Ltd|year=2001|isbn=1-84037-141-2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|RAF Kaldadarnes}} {{Royal Air Force}} [[Category:Royal Air Force stations of World War II in Europe|Kal]] [[Category:World War II sites in Iceland]] {{RAF-stub}}
